Description: Egyptian fragment of Eros in relief, probably from a mould-made oil-lamp, where this functioned as a handle. Eros is depicted wearing a festival wreath over his long curly hair. He is carrying a bow in his left hand and an arrow in his right (now mostly lost). He looks down to his right and appears to be walking in that direction. Mould-made in two-piece mould, with join visible on left wing. Brown Nile silt with abundant fine gold mica and white inclusions. Possibly covered with a red slip. Some traces of post depositional (?) white plaster adhering to face. Missing feet and left wing, tip of arrow and whole of oil-lamp.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Not from a stand alone figure, but instead a group, or more likely, a lamp. Parallel from the Musee Guimet of an Eros decorating a mould made 'Roman' lamp (Dunand 1990, no. 99; E 20717). This type of lamp is dated to the beggining of the Roman period in Egypt (Villing et al 2013-2015, PL.083). Dunand, F. 1990. Musée du Louvre. Département des antiquités égyptiennes. Catalogue des terres cuites grécoromaines d'Egypte. Paris.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KD.072) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4565 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
